values: Our power, which had been out since about 22:45 Friday night, came back around 05:50 this morning. Still don't know what to expect at the office, but at least the AC and fridge are back on. Woot!

For insomnia, I recommend sleeping less than a hundred feet from an overnight highway-construction site.

What's that?  Oh, you want to avoid insomnia? 

Can't help you there...  Sorry for the misunderstanding...

Eagerly awaiting the quart of Barge cement and the leather-strap cutter I ordered yesterday. There's gonna be crafting, mark my words.

Later this year, I plan to design and build my own rope-winder... I'm thinking gearbelts...

I'm not a man who is pure of heart.
I don't say prayers at night.
But I'll still be a man, when the wolfsbane blooms,
And the full moon shines its light.

I will still be this man, with his tarnished heart,
And his green and grasping eyes.
Failing to sleep in the moonlight's glare,
And counting off the hours til sunrise.

There's a reason I've held onto my LJ for nearly a decade. Scrolling back through old posts a couple nights ago, was like reconnecting with those times and events. It was a potent experience... up to the point where my posts just kinda dwindle away to nothing. I have much less recorded here to represent more recent years.

It's not a total blackout; while there's almost nothing on myspace, and facebook just isn't gonna happen, there is stuff elsewhere, entries on flickr and fetlife. There's a ton of secondlife chat and IM logs. But... I like LJ. Really, just that simple.

My time is a lot more rigorously budgeted now than it used to be. I doubt I'll be posting on even a weekly basis, let alone the multiple daily posts I used to enjoy. But when I can, I aim to record my goings-on here, to help me make some coherent sense of the time so rapidly passing.

Namaste.

E

dude.... I still have a livejournal....

eeeeexcellent.....

Some of you know this already, but Rachel and I were recently faced with an unexpected turn in the health of our ten-year-old cat Mallory. I very much regret to say, that Mal passed away this evening after a two week battle with what ultimately proved to be lung cancer. 

We are both feeling this loss very acutely, but are grateful that we were able to spare him further discomfort. We were with him at the end, and let him go with the knowledge that we had done our very best to save him, and that we had given him the best life we possibly could.

I want to thank you all for the kind words and thoughts during this time. We miss him more than I can say, but please know that we will be all right. 

- E

I knew there was a good reason to save that old microwave transformer. One down, one more to go...
ETA one of the best bits of advice from the forum thread on this: 'Do not include yourself in this circuit'... loosely translated as 'ferfscksake be careful'... I may be mad, but I try to at least be responsible you know...  :)

'The Problem With Romance' is a five-song EP, written and performed by e.a.rowe. This is a first run, limited to one hundred hand-numbered discs, and featuring photography by the amazingly multi-talented . These songs deal with issues of obsession, fear, shame... and just a bit of surprisingly resilient hope. Not bad for five bucks. Clicky on picture for ordering info:

<lj-poll-1200647>

I have no particular reason for asking...

Not to say that my hands have been idle lately; still, I do sometimes have nervous energy in need of an outlet. Allow me to present the new Indelicate Instruments 'Hack 408', an electric kalimba. Genuine office-grade paper clip tines have been left lovingly untuned to any known scale: Here's a closer - but fuzzier - view: The speaker is around 4", and was rescued from some boombox or something, I forget. It's wired to a 1/4" jack that lets me plug directly into an amp, so that the speaker becomes a mic, but I can just as easily run it as a speaker, which produces a neat pseudo-reverb from the tines. I am also pleased to report that along the way, my soldering skill has improved from 'nonexistent' to merely 'poor'. My goal is to reach 'adequate' by the end of summer...

My friend once worked as a repair tech for a chain of music stores. I figure this was sometime in the early-to-mid '90s. I went with him a few times when he had to drop by the repair shop, and was always fascinated by all the arcane tools and equipment covering the bench. I got more and more interested, and tried to ask what I hoped were relevant questions. Mike was always happy to explain stuff, but the answers didn't always sink in. I recall that one night I expressed some frustration with the difficulty I was having at the extreme low end of the learning curve, and eventually resulting in the following exchange: Mike:    "So, do you know how a toaster works?" Eric:    "Well, sure." Mike:    "No, really - do you know? Have you looked inside to find out?" It's not often that we're able to point to specific moments as pivotal to our personal evolution, but that was a big one, a cast-iron skillet of satori upside the skull, leaving it permanently dented, but I think more interestingly shaped. Thanks Mike.    :)

Big, bad Mallory, sleepin' in his wubbie: Also: Remember this? Well, now it's electric: Old telecaster neck pickup, salvaged from another diytar and hard-wired to the cable. Works surprisingly well...    :)

"... but why will you say that I am mad?" As proof of my sanity, let me first show off the headstock of my former twelve-string acoustic, now - by the power of Science and a #0 Phillips screwdriver - reborn as an eight-string. Behold the beauty of its gap-toothed maw: More interesting still though, would be the following, a 3/4-size 'student' guitar. Someone at the factory evidently didn't think students would need proper fret placement, with the result that its intonation is completely nonexistent. As a lap steel though, it's fantastic... well, now that I've 'enhanced' it a bit. Here's a closeup of the bridge and tailpiece: ... and another showing the raised action at the headstock: Of course, none of this would be possible without my helpful cat Mallory: ... but all that work sure did make him tired: What does it sound like? For educational purposes, I recorded a short piece to demonstrate. Name that tune, anyone?

Known facts:

1) Americans enjoy coffee.
2) Americans tend to consume large portions of what they enjoy.

Why then, is it so damn difficult to find a cheap coffee mug that holds between 24-32 ounces? I see lots of 16oz, but not much bigger. If this keeps up I may have to actually go check the offerings at Starbucks...

It hasn't yet updated at Podiobooks, but since I've had a few folks lately asking when the next installment would be released, I thought I'd pass along the link: Serve It Cold - Episode 16 Cheers! (... and back to werk for me...)

A couple days ago I was leaving the CVS near my house, and noticed a large splotch of bright yellow-green paint on the asphalt. 

It probably says something about me, that my first thought was to wonder if a wounded Predator might be lurking nearby...

Some of you may know that I spent some time recording an audiobook last year, working alongside our very own , as well as a bunch of other very nice and talented folks. The book is a mystery novel called 'Serve It Cold', by Ronnie Blackwell, set in southern Mississippi and New Orleans. Well, recording wrapped up a while ago, but the editing and post-production are just now hitting the home stretch, and episodes are being released on PodioBooks. There are seven episodes currently available, all free to download, and the first can be streamed directly off the site. This is an awfully cool story, and I feel pretty lucky in getting to be part of the production. I hope folks will consider checking it out, if only to have themselves a good chuckle over my attempted deep southern dialect.    ;)

Good morning y'all. I'm sorry to have dropped off the LJ radar for so long - I don't think I've read more than a handful of posts in the last six weeks. Things have been busy, but for the most part I've been doing okay at keeping up with it all.

One week ago, at this very moment, I was standing by the side of Arlington Boulevard, taking down insurance information for the Audi A4 that plowed into the back of my Bronco at 45mph. Simple stop-and-go traffic incident, happens to lots of folks; no injuries, no acrimony. My bumper has already been replaced, and my frame straightened and found healthy. The insurance folks were very pleasant and professional - big ups to Nationwide Mutual.

The weekend before the accident was our annual Beltane campout, which has been written up elsewhere far better than I have time to do here. Suffice to say that it was a ton of work, but totally worth it. Big, big fun.

Last item on the list is one that's been in the works for a while. This summer will see the release of my first real album, a five-song EP called 'The Problem With Romance'. The genre could best be called Acoustic Darkwave, with tendrils extending into more traditional folk music here and there. The mastering is finished, I like how it sounds, and I hope you will too. More details will be posted here as they become available.

Okay, work is starting to heat up, so I'm afraid that's all I've got time for today. Take care folks, I'll catch you on the flipside.

This is a song that I like a lot, and to which I hope I've done enough justice. I guess it makes a fitting counterpart to the last track I posted, back in early November. Five months is a long time between updates, but fear not, things around here will be jumping soon enough... [ download 5.6 mb ]

When self-engineering my home recordings, I often have trouble getting a guitar sound that I like. I don't think this is the gears fault, my rig is pretty flexible. The problem is simply that I need to hear the guitar playing in order to set the controls right, but when I'm playing the guitar, I can't also be fussing with the controls. Further complication - when playing, the guitar becomes a physical obstacle to reaching said controls. This is why I need a guitar-playing robot. The mk I unit will probably be pretty simple, just a pick mounted to a low-rpm DC motor on a bracket. It won't be able to play chords, but a repeated low-E would at least give me something to help zero in on what I want. Someday though, I'll start playing with solenoids. Those fools at the Academy will rue the day they called me mad...

... that we didn't get a picture yesterday, when I was towing a stranded motorist up a slippery hill, flexing the Bronco's mighty V8. So. Freakin'. Badass.

I'm just sayin'...

Friday:
1. Leave work at 18:00, notice that front left tire on Bronco looks a bit low. Resolve to stop on way home to add more air. 2. Drive one half block down Wilson before rim is scraping ground. Pull into loading zone to change tire. Call to inform that I'll be late getting home. 3. Discover that spare tire bracket plate is broken, preventing removal from spare. Attempt various workarounds, to no avail. Call AAA for assistance. 4. arrives, to keep me company while I wait for AAA. When driver shows up, he is in a pickup, not a tow truck, and is there to help me change the tire. However, the bracket remains stuck, and finally he calls for a tow truck, ETA about an hour. 5. We are expecting guests, so heads home to greet them. Wrecker shows up at about 20:30. Weather is clear but very cold, and I am not dressed for it. By the time I climb up into the cab I'm shivering hard, way down in the solar plexus. 6. Drive home is entertaining. Driver is young, maybe mid-20s, and playing nu-metal on stereo. We are wearing identical Red Kap work jackets, though I doubt he regards his as a fashion statement. We talk about snow and climate change, and what constitutes a really sucky job. It's a little past 21:00 when he finally offloads the Bronco by my house.
Saturday:
Procrastinated. Also picked up Gibson from shop, plays much better.
Sunday:
1. Drag spare tire onto back porch, attack bracket with angle grinder. It doesn't give up easy, but eventually I have a usable spare again. Truck is jacked up, flat is removed, spare bolted in place. 2. Jack is released. When full weight of truck comes down on spare, it is revealed to also be flat. Evidently it had just enough air to look okay, but not enough to hold up the truck. 3. Go inside. Get warm. Pout for about an hour. 4. Notice that snow has started falling. Rush out to finish before snow or ice become obstacles. Jack up truck again, remove flat spare, put heavy jackstand under axle. Wrap plastic bag around brake disc to keep ice off lug threads. Put both flat tires in back of Scion.
Monday:
1. At about 08:00, drives me to work in Scion. We stop to drop off tires at local shop for inspection and repair. 2. At 18:00, she picks me up from work. We return to shop. Total charge is $20; the mechanic has inflated and examined both tires, but found no punctures, just dirt around rims. His theory is that the seal around the rims was broken by debris. I think cold-weather contraction of the metal may have also been a problem. Resolve to watch closely for further pressure loss. 3. Get home, watch tv.
Tuesday:
1. At 06:00, put on warm coat and head back outside. Put spare back in truck, bolt original wheel back in place. Remove stand, lower the jack. Pressure seems to be holding. Go back inside, shower and change. 2. Around 07:30, drive around block. Still no pressure loss, so I drive in to work. No problems during commute. 3. Current time is about 10:15, and pressure still looks good. Will continue to monitor, but I'm allowing some guarded optimism...

Much as I love my gal Faith, I'd never thought much of her stock bridge pins. They were generic white plastic, and had gotten pretty gnarled over her twenty-five years, so that I was beginning to worry about bridge plate damage due to poor string seating. Therefore, after a suitable period of procrastination, I finally decided to outfit her with some spiffy new pins. They're brass, which not only flexes less under pressure, but brightens up the treble a bit to help offset a slight tendency to boominess. Also, they look pretty sweet: In other news, I'm hoping my Gibson will be coming back soon from setup camp. It's been almost two weeks, but that includes completely reshaping the nut, which I am sooo not doing myself...
... 'Your search - "clerical hoodie" - did not match any documents.' Anyone else think this needs to be remedied?

Some type of nasty bug has evidently decided to take up residence in my honey <lj user="fenriss">'s respiratory tract. She's had a moderately high fever since sunday, which hasn't broken yet. We do have her on antibiotics, prescribed by the ER doc we saw sunday night, so with luck we'll see some improvement soon - assuming, of course, that the doctor is right about it being some type of strep, and not tonsillitis, which is frequently viral. Hopefully the culture will be back today to tell us for sure.

There's a good chance that this will wind up cutting into our social life for the next little while, so many apologies to any folks we miss seeing over the next week or so. We'll see you all soon enough, hopefully on the less-contagious side of this thing...

Okay, some of you may know that my cousin Sue is an opera singer. She's had a pretty long career, and I was under the impression that she'd retired to teaching now, but apparently I was mistaken. She's beginning rehearsals for a new opera at the Met, directed by Zhang Yimou and conducted by Tan Dun, and starring Placido Domingo. That is so bloody cool... but I am now having to struggle very hard not to feel like a total underacheiver...

This time of year, it's easy to let one's thoughts turn to darker stuff, and it's sometimes difficult to see the bright side that's supposed to balance eveything out. I'll spare everyone the unnecessary details, but I will say that while I've had a few personal losses this year, I've also been unreasonably lucky, all things considered. I've got a fantastic wife, a loving family, wonderful friends... and I've got my music, to help me vent the harder stuff in ways that don't involve patching up the drywall later. This song has been around for a long time, first recorded by Blind Lemon Jefferson in 1928. I grew up listening to the Bob Dylan version, which was released in 1962, a decade before I was even born. It's been covered by a lot of other folks, which I guess puts me in pretty good company. Anyway, I do hope you folks will like this one. It's a song I've loved for a long time. [ download 5.1 mb ]

First cool thing: Last night I finally tracked down the drivers for my USB-cellphone cable, and am now successfully running BitPim, "a program that allows you to view and manipulate data on many CDMA phones". Also, it's free. Sweet. I celebrated this victory by crafting myself a messed-up new ringtone, a spooky broken fragment of prepared piano. It's creeptastic. Second cool thing: Just now, crossing the street outside my office, I found a wicked-loooking fragment of broken plate glass. It's an acute triangle about three inches long and a quarter-inch thick, and it too was free! Can you believe that? ETA: I... Huh. That's weird...

In what should probably be called an act of sheer hubris, I recently decided to record a dramatic (perhaps even... too dramatic?) reading of Poe's spooky classic. I had tried this one before, back in January, but the results were not to my liking, and I had mostly shelved the idea until my dear nudged me to revive it. Credit her if you like the results; blame me if you don't...    ;) [ download 8.5 mb ]

Hey folks. The past few weeks at werk have been fairly intense, so big apologies if I've missed any massively huge news on LJ recently, I haven't been very active here since... I dunno, early September I guess?

I've also been starting to slip into SAD mode as the year winds down, which is the other reason I've mostly dropped off the radar recently. However, the good news on that front is a change in HedMedz, which will hopefully have my skullguts properly tweaked by early November-ish...

I've been thinking a lot lately about starting a dark folk/acoustic industrial band. Any volunteers?

ETA:
Found:    One bassist, the lovely Ms. <lj user="boadiccea">!
Still wanted:    Laptop jockey, for percussion and mayhem...

They always tell you that a sharp knife is safer than a dull one. That's usually true, but not if you drop it and slash your own leg, as I did just now in my office kitchen. It's maybe 3/4" down the mid-shin, and not deep or even painful, but it bled pretty good for a while - I suspect the bloodstained sock I'm now wearing will be readily identifiable for many laundry loads to come. In brighter news, I snagged myself a nifty guitar on Saturday. It's a black 1997 Gibson Blueshawk, which looks a bit like a shrunken Les Paul, but is actually a thin hollow-body with soapbar pickups. I need to tweak the action a bit, but the tone is really nicely aggressive...
New. Microphone. Just ordered the 46MXL, should be here in a few days. I'm really looking forward to playing with this one...

A: OMG I saw a show! So last night the Wife and I picked up Ms. and headed off to the 9:30, there to see Rollins and X. Ran into and , as well as Slash, who seldom misses a Rollins appearance in DC. Both bands were in 'classic lineup' mode, although HR's bass player was Melvin Gibbs, who is of a slightly more recent vintage. He's a killer bassist though, and a really good guy, if the interview I just read in Tape Op is any indication. While there, I had the weird realization that I had actually been present at the first post-Black Flag Rollins show at the old 9:30. That would have been the 'Lifetime' tour in 1987. Nineteen years ago. I was too young to drive, so and I, along with our friend James, caught a ride with Johnny and in John's old Chevelle. That was my first and only stage-diving experience, and there's a very good chance that the roadie who pushed me off the stage was Joe Cole. Rachel wasn't feeling well, and is still having trouble with a sprained ankle and a bruised toe, so unfortunately we did have to leave before X was done playing. Damn though - they put on a hell of a show. I've never taken the time to get very familiar with their songs, but I guess I'll now have to remedy that...
These are a couple of haiku I wrote a few weeks ago...
I just discovered that my cousin Frank has his own wiki. Nice! If you happen to run into him at GenCon, tell him I said hi, okay?

This morning I dreamed that we went down to the Country Estate, and <lj user="cjpetherick"> gave me a big bowl of kerosene soup. He said that the aged kerosene was a lot more mellow than the fresh stuff, and it actually did taste okay, kind of like chicken broth. No harmful effects followed, but just the same, I think I'll steer clear if someone offers it to me again...

Rachel and I are now home from our day trip to Waynesboro, PA, my family's home town. My grandmother's memorial service was very nice; we saw a few relatives that I hadn't seen in ages, and there was a reading of her favorite poem. I hope, dear friends, that you aren't yet sick of my telling you how much I appreciate you all. Because you know, I surely do. The past week month has been a bit rough, but today... I think I felt something shift a little. It feels like maybe I could let myself relax a little, and not spend each moment fixating on what might go wrong next. I really think I'd like that.

I'm back at work for now. My grandmother's memorial is going to be held next Wednesday, at the family's 'home town' of Waynesboro PA. I think we're all doing pretty well under the circumstances.

I haven't yet got enough energy or presence of mind to reply, but I wanted you all to know how much I appreciate all the supportive comments and emails. You guys are truly the best friends one could hope for.

I got a call from my mom around 9:20 this morning, letting me know that my grandmother had just passed away. It was sooner than the doctors had expected, but she had been ill, and we feel fortunate that she didn't have to suffer through a longer hospital stay. 

Mom and I are doing okay. I'm heading up to Frederick now to do whatever I can to help and be supportive. I don't know how things will shape up over the next few days, but please accept my apologies if I have to cancel on any social plans.

Also, I probably won't be online much for a couple of days, so if there's something important I should know, please drop a line to my gmail account so I don't overlook it.

Thanks folks, love to all.

I've been kinda out of touch with LJ for much of the last two or three weeks. Reserves of time and energy have been running low, due mostly to werk stuff. Hoping things will either settle down a little so I can catch up, or that my energy levels will improve so I'm not dragging so much through the days.

Two cool things from last night though:

1. I made myself a set of new earrings out of some 14g solid copper wire I had lying around. Pretty much just twist, jab, and close with pliers. They're rough-looking and a bit sharp'n'poky, but they make me very happy. 

2. I discovered that my theory on building a homegrown PA rig was correct: 

(guitar + mic) + (laptop + old bass amp) = awesome

I already had a PA, but this one kicks a lot more low end, and the laptop lets me mangle sound on the fly without quite so much cable hassle. Sweeeet...
